unnormalised: **Air Quality Concerns Persist Across North India, Especially Post-Diwali**
normalised: Air Quality Concerns Persist Across North India, Especially Post-Diwali

unnormalised: New Delhi – Air quality across North India continues to be a significant environmental concern, particularly exacerbated following the Diwali festival. The Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) reported elevated levels of PM2.5 and PM10 in several cities, including Kanpur, Lucknow, and even smaller towns like Rohtak.
normalised: New Delhi – Air quality across North India continues to be a significant environmental concern, particularly exacerbated following the Diwali festival. The Central Pollution Control Board (C P C B) reported elevated levels of P M two point five and P M ten in several cities, including Kanpur, Lucknow, and even smaller towns like Rohtak.

unnormalised: According to data released on November 14, 2024, at 10:00 hrs, Delhi's Air Quality Index (AQI) hovered around 'Severe' in many areas, with Anand Vihar topping the charts. Factors contributing to the poor air quality include stubble burning in neighboring states like Punjab and Haryana, vehicular emissions, and industrial pollution.
normalised: According to data released on fourteenth November two thousand and twenty four, at ten o’clock, Delhi's Air Quality Index (A Q I) hovered around 'Severe' in many areas, with Anand Vihar topping the charts. Factors contributing to the poor air quality include stubble burning in neighboring states like Punjab and Haryana, vehicular emissions, and industrial pollution.

unnormalised: Experts from IIT-Kanpur are conducting ongoing research to identify specific sources of pollutants and model their dispersal patterns. The Graded Response Action Plan (GRAP) remains in effect, with stricter measures implemented since October 20, 2024, including a ban on construction activities and restrictions on diesel vehicles. Individuals, especially those with respiratory ailments and children, are advised to stay indoors as much as possible and use N95 masks when venturing out. The CPCB will release its next report on November 15, 2024, at 17:00 hrs.
normalised: Experts from I I T-Kanpur are conducting ongoing research to identify specific sources of pollutants and model their dispersal patterns. The Graded Response Action Plan (G R A P) remains in effect, with stricter measures implemented since twentieth October two thousand and twenty four, including a ban on construction activities and restrictions on diesel vehicles. Individuals, especially those with respiratory ailments and children, are advised to stay indoors as much as possible and use N ninety five masks when venturing out. The C P C B will release its next report on fifteenth November two thousand and twenty four, at five o’clock.
